questions.text: All are LARC except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Tubal ligation. Long-acting reversible contraception (LARC) methods are highly effective forms of birth control that, once administered, can prevent pregnancy for an extended period without requiring daily, weekly, or monthly action from the user. They are also reversible, meaning fertility can return after removal. Tubal ligation, while a highly effective and long-term birth control method, is considered a permanent sterilization procedure rather than a reversible one. It involves surgically blocking or severing the fallopian tubes, making it extremely difficult, if not impossible, to reverse and regain fertility. Therefore, it does not fit the "reversible" criterion of LARC. Implants (A) are a type of LARC. These are small, flexible rods inserted under the skin of the upper arm that release hormones to prevent pregnancy for up to three to five years. They are easily removable, and fertility quickly returns. IUDs (B), or intrauterine devices, are also a type of LARC. These small devices are inserted into the uterus and can prevent pregnancy for three to ten years, depending on the type (hormonal or copper). They are highly effective and can be removed at any time, with fertility returning promptly. Injectable contraception (D), such as Depo-Provera, is not considered a LARC. While it provides contraception for a longer period than daily pills (typically three months per injection), it requires repeat injections at regular intervals to maintain effectiveness. The "long-acting" aspect of LARC generally refers to methods that last for at least a year without further user action, which injectables do not meet.

questions.text: A girl presented with amenorrhea. Which of the following will be classified as primary amenorrhea
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 14-year-old with Tanner Stage 1 breast development. Primary amenorrhea is defined as the absence of menstruation by a certain age, often in conjunction with the presence or absence of secondary sexual characteristics. There are two key criteria for diagnosing primary amenorrhea: Absence of any secondary sexual characteristics (like breast development) by age 13. Absence of menarche by age 15, even with normal secondary sexual characteristics. Absence of menarche within 3 years of thelarche (onset of breast development, typically Tanner Stage 2). In option A, a 14-year-old with Tanner Stage 1 breast development (meaning no breast development) clearly meets the criteria for primary amenorrhea. At 14, a girl should have started puberty (Tanner Stage 2 breast development is the first sign) and likely menarche, or at the very least, have clear signs of pubertal progression. The complete absence of breast development at this age is a significant red flag. B. 13-year-old with Tanner Stage 5 breast development: Tanner Stage 5 breast development indicates full adult breast development. While menarche typically occurs around Tanner Stage 4, it's possible for a girl to have reached Tanner Stage 5 without having had her first period yet, especially if she is only 13. However, given the advanced breast development, it's less likely to be classified as primary amenorrhea based on the lack of any secondary sexual characteristics. The more immediate concern would be if she hasn't had menarche within 3 years of her initial breast development. If her breast development started very early, say at 8 or 9, then at 13 without menarche, it might meet the 3-year criterion for primary amenorrhea, but simply Tanner Stage 5 at 13 doesn't automatically classify it. C. 12-year-old with Tanner Stage 4 breast development: Similar to option B, Tanner Stage 4 breast development indicates significant pubertal progression. Menarche commonly occurs around this stage. At 12, a girl with such advanced breast development is well within the typical range for puberty and would be expected to have menarche soon, if not already. This scenario does not meet the criteria for primary amenorrhea. D. 11-year-old with Tanner Stage 1 breast development: While Tanner Stage 1 means no breast development, an 11-year-old is still within the normal age range for the onset of puberty. Puberty can begin anywhere from 8 to 13 years old. Therefore, at 11, the lack of breast development alone isn't immediately indicative of primary amenorrhea as she may still enter puberty at a typical time. This would only become a concern if she remains in Tanner Stage 1 past age 13.

questions.text: Cancer caused by DES
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Clear cell cancer of the vagina. Diethylstilbestrol (DES) is a synthetic estrogen that was prescribed to pregnant women between 1940 and 1971 to prevent complications such as miscarriage and premature birth. It was later discovered that in utero exposure to DES (meaning exposure while the female fetus was in the womb) significantly increased the risk of developing a rare type of vaginal and cervical cancer called clear cell adenocarcinoma in these "DES daughters." This cancer typically presented when the DES daughters were in their teens or early twenties, although cases have been reported in older women as well. The link between DES and clear cell adenocarcinoma is one of the most well-known examples of a transplacental carcinogen. A. Sarcoma botryoides: This is a rare, aggressive type of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, primarily affecting the vagina, bladder, or cervix, most commonly seen in infants and young children. It presents as a "grape-like" mass. Its occurrence is not linked to DES exposure. B. Squamous cell cancer of the vagina: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of vaginal cancer, but its primary risk factor is human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, particularly high-risk types of HPV. While DES daughters may have some structural abnormalities of the vagina, squamous cell cancer is not specifically caused by DES. C. Paget's disease of the vagina: Paget's disease of the vulva (or vagina, though less common) is a rare intraepithelial adenocarcinoma that presents as a red, itchy, eczematous lesion. Its exact cause is not fully understood, but it is not directly linked to DES exposure.

questions.text: Sequence of steps in D&C A. Assess uterus direction and size B. Uterine sound C. Serial dilatation D. Curettage
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A, B, C, D. Dilation and curettage (D&C) is a common gynecological procedure involving the dilation (opening) of the cervix and the curettage (scraping) of the uterine lining. The sequence of steps is crucial for the safety and effectiveness of the procedure. A. Assess uterus direction and size: This is the initial and critical step. Before any instruments are inserted into the uterus, the physician must carefully perform a bimanual pelvic examination to determine the position (ante-flexed, retro-flexed) and approximate size of the uterus. This assessment helps to guide the subsequent insertion of instruments, reducing the risk of uterine perforation. B. Uterine sound: After assessing the uterus, a uterine sound (a long, thin, malleable instrument with markings) is gently inserted through the cervix into the uterine cavity. This step precisely measures the depth of the uterine cavity, confirming the earlier bimanual assessment and providing essential information for the safe use of other instruments, particularly the curette. It also helps to confirm the uterine direction. C. Serial dilatation: Once the uterine depth and direction are confirmed, the cervix needs to be gradually opened to allow the passage of the curette. This is achieved by using a series of progressively larger dilators, inserted gently one after another until the desired degree of cervical dilation is achieved. This step is critical to prevent cervical trauma. D. Curettage: With the cervix adequately dilated, the curette (a spoon-shaped instrument with a sharp or blunt edge) is then inserted into the uterine cavity. The uterine lining is gently and systematically scraped to remove tissue, which might be for diagnostic purposes (e.g., endometrial biopsy for abnormal bleeding) or therapeutic purposes (e.g., evacuation of retained products of conception after a miscarriage). The other options are incorrect because they present an incomplete or incorrect sequence of these essential steps. B. A and B: This option only includes the initial assessment and sounding, omitting the crucial steps of dilation and curettage necessary to complete the procedure. C. A, C and D: This option omits the use of the uterine sound (B). While one might argue that careful assessment can provide some information, the uterine sound provides a precise, objective measurement of uterine depth, which is vital before proceeding with dilation and curettage to prevent perforation. D. B and D: This option skips the initial uterine assessment (A) and serial dilation (C), making the procedure unsafe. Inserting a uterine sound or curette without prior assessment and adequate dilation significantly increases the risk of uterine perforation and cervical trauma.

questions.text: Which part of HPV virus is sued to make the vaccine
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) L1. The Human Papillomavirus (HPV) vaccines are designed to prevent infection by specific types of HPV that cause various cancers (like cervical, anal, and throat cancers) and genital warts. These vaccines are made using a specific protein from the HPV virus. L1 (Major Capsid Protein): The HPV vaccines are made from virus-like particles (VLPs). These VLPs are formed by the self-assembly of the L1 major capsid protein of the HPV virus. The L1 protein is the main structural protein that makes up the outer shell (capsid) of the virus. When this protein is produced in a lab (using recombinant DNA technology, often in yeast cells), it can spontaneously assemble into a structure that looks like the actual virus but contains no viral genetic material. This means the VLPs are non-infectious and cannot cause disease. However, they are highly immunogenic, meaning they effectively trigger the body's immune system to produce antibodies against HPV. These antibodies can then neutralize real HPV viruses if a person is exposed to them in the future, providing protection against infection. A. E6: E6 is an early protein of the HPV virus. In high-risk HPV types, E6 (along with E7) plays a crucial role in the development of cancer by interfering with host cell growth regulatory pathways (e.g., targeting p53 for degradation). While E6 is important for viral replication and oncogenesis, it is not used to make the prophylactic vaccines because including it could potentially carry oncogenic risks or not elicit the necessary protective neutralizing antibodies. B. E7: Similar to E6, E7 is also an early protein involved in HPV-related cancer development. It primarily targets the retinoblastoma protein (Rb), another key cell cycle regulator. For the same reasons as E6, E7 is not used in prophylactic HPV vaccines. However, these oncoproteins are being explored in the development of therapeutic HPV vaccines, which aim to treat existing HPV infections or HPV-related cancers by eliciting a cellular immune response against infected cells. D. E1: E1 is an early protein of the HPV virus that functions as a helicase, essential for viral DNA replication. While vital for the virus's life cycle, it is not the structural protein that forms the viral capsid and elicits the protective neutralizing antibody response needed for a prophylactic vaccine.

questions.text: Vulval cancer most common in age group
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 65-85. Vulval cancer is predominantly a disease of older women. The incidence of vulval cancer significantly increases with age, with the majority of cases diagnosed in postmenopausal women. A. 65-85: This age range accurately represents the demographic where vulval cancer is most commonly diagnosed. Studies consistently show that the average or median age at diagnosis for vulval cancer is around 70 years old. More than half of all cases occur in women over 70, and a significant percentage are diagnosed in women aged 65 and above. For instance, some data indicates that over 4 in 10 new cases (42%) are in females aged 75 and over in the UK, and in the US, the majority of cases fall within the 70-84 age group. B. 35-55: While vulval cancer can occur in younger women, especially those with certain risk factors like HPV infection, it is far less common in this age group compared to older women. This range represents a much smaller proportion of total vulval cancer cases. C. Below 18: Vulval cancer is extremely rare in individuals under the age of 18. This age group accounts for a negligible percentage of diagnoses. D. None: Since option A accurately identifies the most common age group, "None" is incorrect. It's important to note that while age is a significant risk factor, other factors like HPV infection, smoking, a weakened immune system, and certain chronic inflammatory vulvar conditions (e.g., lichen sclerosus) also contribute to the risk, and some types of vulval cancer are more associated with younger women and HPV. However, when considering the overall most common age group, it is definitively in older age.

questions.text: All are risk factors for vulvar cancer except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Vulvar hamartoma. Vulvar cancer is a relatively rare cancer, but several well-established risk factors contribute to its development. A vulvar hamartoma is a benign (non-cancerous) growth consisting of a disorganized but mature mixture of tissues normally found in the vulva. It is a developmental anomaly and does not carry an increased risk of malignancy or progression to cancer. Therefore, it is not considered a risk factor for vulvar cancer. A. Vulvar dystrophy (specifically chronic inflammatory conditions like Lichen Sclerosus): Vulvar dystrophies, particularly chronic inflammatory conditions such as lichen sclerosus and lichen planus, are significant risk factors for vulvar squamous cell carcinoma, which is the most common type of vulvar cancer. These conditions cause chronic inflammation, itching, thinning, and scarring of the vulvar skin, which can lead to cellular changes over time, increasing the risk of malignant transformation. B. Smoking: Smoking is a well-recognized risk factor for various cancers, including vulvar cancer. Carcinogens in tobacco smoke can directly damage DNA and impair the immune system's ability to clear HPV infections, thereby increasing the risk of HPV-associated vulvar cancers. Even for non-HPV related vulvar cancers, smoking can contribute to chronic inflammation and cellular changes that predispose to malignancy. D. HPV (Human Papillomavirus): Infection with high-risk types of Human Papillomavirus (HPV), particularly HPV 16 and 18, is a major risk factor for vulvar cancer, especially in younger women. HPV infection can lead to precancerous lesions known as vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN), which, if left untreated, can progress to invasive vulvar cancer. A significant proportion of vulvar squamous cell carcinomas are associated with HPV infection.

questions.text: All are additional benefits of oral contraceptives except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) HIV and STDs. Oral contraceptives (OCs), while highly effective for preventing pregnancy and offering several non-contraceptive health benefits, provide absolutely no protection against sexually transmitted infections (STIs), including HIV. They do not create a physical barrier to prevent the transmission of viruses or bacteria during sexual contact. Therefore, individuals using OCs still need to use barrier methods like condoms to protect themselves from STIs. B. Endometrial cancer: Combined oral contraceptives (COCs), which contain both estrogen and progestin, significantly reduce the risk of endometrial cancer. The progestin component of COCs helps to thin the endometrial lining, counteracting the proliferative effects of estrogen and thereby reducing the risk of abnormal cell growth that could lead to cancer. The protective effect increases with the duration of COC use and persists for many years after discontinuation. C. Ovarian cancer: COCs also provide substantial protection against ovarian cancer. The mechanism is thought to involve the suppression of ovulation; by reducing the number of ovulations over a woman's lifetime, OCs decrease the number of times the ovarian surface epithelium is disrupted, which is believed to be a contributing factor to ovarian cancer development. Like endometrial cancer, the protective effect increases with duration of use and can last for decades after stopping the pill. D. Ectopic pregnancy: While OCs do not treat an ectopic pregnancy, they significantly reduce the risk of developing one. Since OCs work primarily by preventing ovulation, they drastically lower the chance of fertilization occurring. If fertilization does not occur, then an ectopic pregnancy (where a fertilized egg implants outside the uterus, most commonly in the fallopian tube) cannot happen. By effectively preventing pregnancy altogether, they inherently reduce the risk of all types of pregnancy, including ectopic ones.

questions.text: Webbed neck, amenorrhea, normal intelligence streak ovaries
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Key Physical Features of Turner Syndrome (45,XO) Turner syndrome is a chromosomal disorder affecting females, caused by complete or partial loss of one X chromosome. It leads to characteristic physical, reproductive, and systemic anomalies. Key Physical Features: 1. Short Stature – Growth failure is common, with an average adult height of ~4’8” (142-148 cm) without growth hormone therapy. 2. Webbed Neck (Pterygium Colli) - Excess skin folds on the sides of the neck. 3. Low Posterior Hairline - Hairline extends lower on the back of the neck. 4. Shield Chest - Broad chest with widely spaced nipples. 5. Cubitus Valgus - Increased carrying angle of the elbows. 6. Short 4th Metacarpal/Brachymetacarpia - Shortening of the fourth finger. 7. Lymphedema at Birth - Puffy hands and feet due to lymphatic dysfunction. 8. High-Arched Palate - May cause feeding and speech difficulties. 9. Nail Dysplasia - Small, hyperconvex, or ridged nails. 10. Micrognathia - Small jaw, sometimes leading to dental malocclusion. Associated Features: • Cardiac Abnormalities - Coarctation of the aorta, bicuspid aortic valve. • Renal Anomalies - Horseshoe kidney, duplicated collecting system. • Gonadal Dysgenesis (Streak Ovaries) - Leads to primary amenorrhea and infertility. • Osteoporosis & Delayed Puberty - Due to estrogen deficiency.

choices.text: If recurs in >6 months then platinum sensitive
If recurs between 6-12 months then partially sensitive

questions.text: Regarding Ovarian cancer recurrence
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Platinum Sensitivity in Ovarian Cancer - Detailed Classification The classification is based on the platinum-free interval (PFI) - the time from completion of platinum-based chemotherapy to the first recurrence. 1. Platinum-Sensitive • Definition: Recurrence >6 months after last platinum-based chemotherapy • Subdivided into: a. Fully Platinum-Sensitive • PFI >12 months • Tumors tend to respond very well to platinum-based rechallenge • Often considered for secondary cytoreduction surgery if feasible • Best prognosis among recurrent disease b. Partially Platinum-Sensitive • PFI between 6–12 months • Intermediate response rate to platinum • May respond to platinum rechallenge but not as durable • May require combination with other agents or switch in regimen 2. Platinum-Resistant • PFI <6 months • Low likelihood of response to platinum • Alternative regimens used: liposomal doxorubicin, topotecan, bevacizumab, etc. • Prognosis is generally poorer 3. Platinum-Refractory • Disease progresses during platinum therapy or within 4 weeks of last dose • Very poor prognosis • Often considered for clinical trials or supportive care

questions.text: Which of the following is more commonly associated with Kallmans syndrome?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Kallmann syndrome is a form of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism caused by defective migration of GnRH-secreting neurons and olfactory neurons during embryogenesis. Key Features of Kallmann Syndrome: • Delayed or absent puberty (due to low GnRH → low FSH & LH) • Anosmia or hyposmia (absent or reduced sense of smell) - hallmark feature • More common in males, but can occur in females too • Primary amenorrhea in girls • Normal karyotype (46, XX or 46, XY)

questions.text: By giving 5 alpha reductase inhibtiors. Mark correct options
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 5-alpha reductase inhibitors (e.g., finasteride, dutasteride) block the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT). What happens hormonally? • DHT levels fall, but testosterone levels may increase slightly due to reduced feedback from DHT. • Testosterone still provides negative feedback to the hypothalamus and pituitary. • As a result, LH and FSH may slightly reduce or remain unchanged - they do not increase. So, among the options, A is the best fit, though in reality, changes in LH/FSH are usually mild and variable.

questions.text: 37-year-old unmarried female, whose mother had breast CA at 50 years of age and sister had cancer at 40 years of age, comes for regular checkup. She is sexually active and taking OCPs for contraception. What will you advise as next step ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) This 37-year-old woman has a strong family history of breast cancer: • Mother diagnosed at 50 years • Sister diagnosed at 40 years • Patient is under 40 and asymptomatic This pattern is suggestive of a hereditary breast cancer syndrome, most notably BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation. Why Genetic Counseling and BRCA Testing? • She meets criteria for genetic risk evaluation based on: • First-degree relatives affected • One diagnosis before age 50 • Genetic counseling helps assess: • Personal and family risk • Implications of BRCA status • Reproductive and preventive options (e.g., surveillance, prophylactic surgery)

questions.text: A 17 year old girl with increased facial hair, her ovaries are bulky 30ml and 40 ml. First line in management are: A. Weight reduction B. OCP C. Spironolactone D. Laparoscopic ovarian drilling
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) This 17-year-old girl has facial hair (suggesting hyperandrogenism) and enlarged ovaries (30 mL and 40 mL), which is well above the normal ovarian volume (< 10 mL), pointing toward PCOS. In adolescents with PCOS, the first-line management includes: • Lifestyle modification, especially weight reduction in overweight or obese individuals. This helps improve insulin sensitivity, reduce androgen levels, and regulate cycles. • Combined oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are also first-line. They help regulate menstrual cycles, reduce androgen production, and improve acne and hirsutism. • Spironolactone is an anti-androgen and is used to treat hirsutism, but only after OCPs have been tried for at least 6 months. It’s not the very first step but still considered part of first-line pharmacologic options in adolescents. • Laparoscopic ovarian drilling (LOD) is not first-line treatment, especially in adolescents. It is invasive and generally reserved for women wit

questions.text: Not true about clomiphene citrate
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Clomiphene citrate is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) used for ovulation induction, especially in women with PCOS or anovulatory infertility. A) Causes endometrial thinning Clomiphene acts as an anti-estrogen at the endometrial level, leading to thinning of the endometrium in some women, which may impair implantation. B) Causes monofollicular development This is the incorrect statement, hence the correct answer. • Clomiphene can lead to the development of multiple follicles, not just one. • Multiple ovulations can occur, increasing the risk of multiple gestation (twins ~5-10%). C) Inhibits negative feedback on GnRH Clomiphene blocks estrogen receptors at the hypothalamus, preventing negative feedback. This leads to increased GnRH, which stimulates FSH and LH release, promoting follicular development. D) Can be used with gonadotropins In resistant cases

questions.text: Fixative used in PAP smear
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The fixative used for a Pap smear is typically a 95% ethanol solution or a spray fixative containing alcohol (such as isopropanol, ethanol, or methanol) to rapidly preserve the cellular morphology. Types of Fixatives: 1. Liquid-Based Cytology (LBC) Fixatives – Used in ThinPrep or SurePath systems. • ThinPrep: Uses a methanol-based preservative. • SurePath: Uses an ethanol-based fixative with other stabilizing agents. 2. Conventional Pap Smear Fixatives: • 95% Ethanol – Gold standard for immediate wet fixation. • Spray Fixatives – Contain alcohol and polyethylene glycol to prevent air-drying. Fixation Process: • Wet Fixation: The slide is immediately placed in 95% ethanol for at least 15–30 minutes. • Spray Fixation: The slide is sprayed from a 15–20 cm distance to avoid dislodging cells. Proper fixation is crucial to prevent air-drying artifacts and ensure accurate cytological evaluation.

questions.text: Image of vulval pathology:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The gross appearance of vulvar cancer can vary depending on the type and stage of the disease. However, common gross features include: 1. Exophytic (Raised) Lesions – Cauliflower-like, warty, or fungating masses. 2. Ulcerated Lesions – Irregular, necrotic, and non-healing ulcers with raised, indurated edges. 3. Plaque-like Lesions – White, red, or pigmented thickened areas on the vulva. 4. Nodular Masses – Firm, irregular, and sometimes infiltrative nodules. 5. Leukoplakia or Erythroplakia – White (hyperkeratotic) or red patches that may progress to invasive carcinoma. 6. Fissures or Erosions – Often painful and associated with chronic irritation. 7. Necrosis and Bleeding – Advanced tumors may show areas of necrosis, friability, and spontaneous bleeding. Common Sites: • Most commonly affects the labia majora, but can also involve the labia minora, clitoris, or perineum. Histologically, squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the most common type of vulvar cancer, followed by rare types like melanoma or adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: Match the karyotype
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 1. Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) Syndrome • Karyotype: 46,XX • Description: A congenital condition causing Müllerian agenesis, leading to the absence or underdevelopment of the uterus and upper vagina while having normal ovarian function and female secondary sexual characteristics. • Gonads: Functional ovaries • Phenotype: Female 2. Turner Syndrome • Karyotype: 45,X (Most common) or Mosaicism (e.g., 45,X/46,XX or 45,X/46,XY) • Description: A chromosomal disorder in females caused by the partial or complete absence of one X chromosome, leading to short stature, ovarian dysgenesis (streak ovaries), and primary amenorrhea. • Gonads: Streak gonads (underdeveloped, fibrotic ovaries) • Phenotype: Female 3. Swyer Syndrome (Complete Gonadal Dysgenesis) • Karyotype: 46,XY • Description: A condition where an individual has a typical male karyotype but develops as a phenotypic female due to dysfunctional SRY gene or gonadal dysgenesis, leading to absent testicular function and no testosterone or AMH production. • Gonads: Streak gonads (nonfunctional, increased malignancy risk) • Phenotype: Female (no secondary sexual development, primary amenorrhea) 4. Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS) • Karyotype: 46,XY • Description: A condition caused by mutations in the androgen receptor (AR) gene, leading to resistance to androgens. This results in incomplete or absent masculinization despite normal or high testosterone levels. • Types: • Complete AIS (CAIS): Female external genitalia, absent uterus, undescended testes. • Partial AIS (PAIS): Variable degree of undervirilization, ambiguous genitalia. • Gonads: Testes (undescended or in inguinal canal) • Phenotype: Female (CAIS) or ambiguous (PAIS)

Volume : 1.4ml 3. Morphology : 4% 4. Total motility : 42% 5. Progressive motility : 30% 6. Vitality : 54% live

PCOS - 1. high LH, 2. normal FSH (sometimes low), 3. E2 levels are normal, 4. SHBG : low, 5. Testosterone levels : slightly raised 6. DHEAS - slightly raised 7. TSH & PROLACTIN- NORMAL

questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Male Pseudohermaphrodite 46 XY BECAUSE OF NO FORMATION OF DHT → EXTERNAL GENITALIA BECOMES FEMALE LIKE. MOST COMMON CAUSE OF FEMALE PSEUDOHERMAPHRODITE- Congenital adrenal hyperplasia [CAH] TRUE HERMAPHRODITE- OVOTESTES - functional tissue of both gonads, most common karyotype is 46XX, ambiguous genitalia.

questions.text: Steps of taking PAP smear A. Vaginal retractor B. Scrape ectocervix C. Making thin smear D. Fxation
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 1. Explain the Procedure to the Patient • Gain informed consent and ensure privacy and comfort. 2. Position the Patient • Place the patient in the lithotomy position on the examination table. 3. Insert the Speculum (Vaginal Retractor) • Gently insert a sterile speculum into the vagina to visualize the cervix clearly. 4. Inspect the Cervix • Look for any obvious lesions, discharge, or abnormalities. 5. Collect the Sample Use: Ayre’s spatula to scrape cells from the ectocervix (rotate 360°). • Optionally, use an endocervical brush to collect cells from the endocervical canal (especially in women >30 years). 6. Prepare the Smear on a Slide • Quickly and evenly spread the collected material on a clean glass slide in a thin layer. 7. Fix the Smear Immediately • Use a fixative spray or place the slide in 95% ethanol to avoid air-drying artifacts. 8. Label and Send to Lab • Label the slide with patient information and send it to the pathology lab with a filled requisition form. 9. Document the Procedure • Record details in the patient’s chart, including the method used and any observations.

questions.text: Which Is Not Used In A Woman With PCOS With Hirsutism And Infertility
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) OCP Drug of choice is letrozole Metformin used when there is insulin resistance Tamoxifen can be used for OI in PCOS replacing clomiphene. OCPs are not used for infertility OCPs are the drug of choice for PCOS in general, and also drug of choice for Hirsutism.

questions.text: Klinefelter syndrome karyotype what is seen
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Klinefelter syndrome is a chromosomal disorder affecting males who have an extra X chromosome. It is the most common chromosomal cause of male hypogonadism and infertility. Key Clinical Features: 1. Physical Features: • Tall stature with long legs and arms (eunuchoid body habitus) • Gynecomastia (breast development) • Small, firm testes (testicular atrophy) • Sparse facial and body hair • Broad hips • Reduced muscle mass 2. Reproductive Features: • Primary testicular failure (hypergonadotropic hypogonadism) • Low testosterone • Elevated FSH and LH • Infertility due to azoospermia or severely reduced sperm count • Delayed or incomplete puberty (in some cases) 3. Cognitive and Behavioral Features: • Mild learning disabilities • Language delay, especially expressive language • Poor executive function or attention issues • May be socially shy or have difficulty with interpersonal relationships 4. Metabolic and Other Associations: • Increased risk of: • Metabolic syndrome and type 2 diabetes • Osteoporosis (due to low testosterone) • Breast cancer (higher risk than other males) • Autoimmune diseases (e.g., lupus, rheumatoid arthritis)

questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) L1 HPV vaccine is made up of VLP’s formed of L1 capsid protein. L1 gene of specific HPV types is recombined into host genome of yeast saccharomyces cerevisiae or insect virus baculovirus. VLP’s lack DNA and are non infectious and non oncogenic Strains of HPV VACCINE → GARDASIL 9 : 6, 11,16,18,31,33,45,52,58. GARDASIL: 6,11,16,18 : QUADRIVALENT CERVARIX : 16,18 MOST IMPORTANT S/E OF HPV VACCINE : syncopal attack Screening has to continue. CI in pregnancy.

choices.text: Screening of other cancer of female genital tract

questions.text: A patient of recurrent trichomoniasis is asked to undergo PAP smear. What is the importance of doing PAP smear
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) A Pap smear (Papanicolaou test) is a screening test, not a diagnostic one. Its main purpose is to detect premalignant and malignant changes in the cervical epithelium. Why it’s relevant in a patient with recurrent trichomoniasis: • Chronic infections, including Trichomonas vaginalis, can cause persistent inflammation of the cervix. • This chronic inflammation can lead to cellular atypia, making it important to screen for cervical cancer or pre-cancerous changes. • While Trichomonas organisms may be seen on a Pap smear, that’s not its primary purpose. Why other options are incorrect: • A) Diagnosis of cervical cancer - Pap smear is a screening, not a definitive diagnostic test. Diagnosis requires colposcopy + biopsy. • C) Diagnosis of trichomoniasis - Not reliable; wet mount or NAAT is used for diagnosis. • D) Screening of other genital tract cancers - Pap smear is specific for cervical epithelium, not for uterus, ovaries, or vulva.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a mechanism of action of OCPs
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Increases gonadotropins MAIN MECHANISM OF ACTION OF OCP IS SUPPRESSION OF OVULATION. INHIBITION OF FSH is more than INHIBITION OF LH. PREVENTS IMPLANTATION as it makes the endometrium thin, which is not suitable for implantation. Cervical mucus thickening done by progesterone. Ocp has estrogen and progesterone and it does a feedback inhibition at HP axis and cause suppression of HPA axis hence the gonadotropin levels will be decreased and not increased

questions.text: 50 year old lady presents with abnormal uterine bleeding for 2 months. What is the next step in management
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Endometrial aspiration cytology/endometrial biopsy A lady who is 45 years or beyond and presents with abnormal uterine bleeding for her endometrial sampling should be done. We will prefer to do outpatient endometrial sampling in the form of endometrial biopsy or endometrial aspiration cytology. Patient less than 45 years, has AUB & has risk factors for endometrial cancer [PCOS/OBESITY/LYNCH syndrome] → we must do endometrial sampling. Postmenopausal bleeding- Endometrial thickness >4 MM → ENDOMETRIAL SAMPLING.

questions.text: A 30 year old female was diagnosed with unilateral breast cancer, she was put on tamoxifen. Risk of which of the following will be increased
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Increased risk of endometrial cancer Tamoxifen is a SERM and has an agonist action at the endometrium and when give for long time like in breast cancer patients can increase risk of endometrial cancer. AT THE LEVEL OF UTERUS- it causes endometrial hyperplasia, endometrial cancer, endometrial polyp. Raloxifene doesn't increase cancer. SERM cause hot flashes [most common SE].

questions.text: Which of the following is done for cervical cancer screening
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 21-65 years Screening for cervical cancer should begin at 21 years of age as per international guidelines and with PAPS alone[21-29years] it is done every 3 yearly while with PAPS and HPV testing together [>30years] it is done every 5 yearly Screening is stopped at 65 years of age if all the PAP smears in last decade are normal.

questions.text: 38 year old lady presented to gynae OPD with cytology report showing HSIL , next step will be
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Colposcopy Cytology is PAP smear report. For HSIL we must follow up with colposcopic directed biopsy and endocervical curettage, irrespective of age.

questions.text: All are used in the treatment of PCOS except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ulipristal Ulipristal is an emergency contraceptive agent and is not used in women with PCOS While clomiphene citrate, letrozole and ovarian drilling are used for ovulation induction in women with PCOS

questions.text: A 32 year old lady presents to infertility clinic, she has regular cycles of 28 days. Ovulation ca be con?rmed with
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Progesterone levels on day 21 Serum progesterone levels are done 7 days before the expected date of menses and in this patient it will be done on day 21. It is a common, easiest and reliable test of ovulation. Levels >3ng : ovulatory cycles. Endometrial biopsy: done in premenstrual phase - Day 26 Hsg done in post menstrual phase : Day 5 to Day 11 [most commonly : Day 10]

questions.text: A 45 year old multiparous woman incidentally diagnosed clinically with 14 week size ?broid. What is the next line of management
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Expectant management Perimenopausal women are candidates for expectant management as fibroids will regress after menopause. In expectant management we do serial follow up with history and examination and if required with imaging Asymptomatic fibroid: no treatment EXCEPT : 1. Asymptomatic patient with infertility & submucosal fibroid → hysteroscopic myomectomy done 2. On CS : incidental pedunculated subserosal fibroid seen → myomectomy done. 3. Infertility with bilateral cornual fibroids : → myomectomy

questions.text: What is the procedure where these are used
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pap smear Ayres spatula & endocervical brush. Bifid end of the spatula is used to take the PAP SMEAR, kept on the transformation zone, rotate it 360° & make a smear out of it. 1st the sample is taken from the transformation zone & then the brush is put in endocervix rotated, brush is rolled on the same slide as the smear, without air drying, put in the fixative for 15 to 20 mins & sent for cytology. Pap smear is only a screening test, it is a cytology test.

questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Gardasil Quadrivalent -16,18,6,11

questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Metronidazole Clindamycin can also be given TREATMENT IN BV - Only when patient is symptomatic, otherwise not necessary to treat bacterial vaginosis. Treatment done cause bacterial vaginosis is associated with preterm labour.

questions.text: In GTN, lung metastasis belongs to which stage?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Stage-3 Canon Ball lung metastasis Good prognosis, Low risk GTN : WHO SCORE <6 : single agent chemotherapy : METHOTREXATE : MULTIDOSE REGIMEN, methotrexate alternated with folinic acid. 2nd most common site of metastasis is vagina [30%] : bluish suburethral nodules seen Stage 4 : High risk GTN >7 :MULTIAGENT CHEMOTHERAPY : EMACO. PERIOD OF SURVEILLANCE FOR GTN : 12MONTHS.

questions.text: A 40-years patient c/o foul smelling grayish white discharge, diagnosed to be Gardenerella vaginalis infection. Microscopic findings are suggestive of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Bacteria adherent to lining vaginal epithelial cells Boundaries of margin not clear: clue cells. Amsel criteria : any 3 out of 4 : 1. Foul smelling discharge 2. Ph >4.5 3. Presence of clue cells 4. Positive whiff test. Best test to confirm diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis : gram staining [Nugent score 7-10 confirms BV]

questions.text: Continuous GnRH is useful in all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Male infertility Continuous GnRH : Initial response is increase in LH & FSH [flare response] → levels are high → negative feedback on hypothalamus → HPO axis suppressed. Continuous GnRH causes ovarian suppression, estrogen production from the ovary will reduce. Drug of choice for precocious puberty is continuous GnRh [cannot be given oral] Given IM/SC/NASAL SPRAY Continuous GnRh also used for : 1. Breast cancer 2. Fibroid uterus 3. Hirsutism 4. AUB S/E : HOT FLASHES, BONE LOSS CONTINUOUS GnRh given with a small amount of estrogen added to it [Add back therapy]. PULSATILE GnRH used for delayed puberty & ovulation induction for infertility.

questions.text: Assertion: Menopause shows hot flashes Reason: Hot flashes are because of low estrogen or tisfluctuation
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Both Assertion and Reasons are true and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion Hot flashes : indication to give HRT in postmenopausal women. If uterus is intact : estrogen + progesterone given If it is a post hysterectomy patient [uterus absent] : estrogen alone given. Estrogen + progesterone : Increase risk of breast cancer. HRT for hot flashes : systemic : transdermal >> oral Atrophy of vagina : topical estrogen given.

questions.text: Hormone therapy is not indicated in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) or Menopausal Hormone Therapy (MHT) has several indications, but also important contraindications. Indications of HRT: • Hot flashes (vasomotor symptoms) - Effective • Osteoporosis prevention - Especially in early postmenopausal women not tolerating other options • Vaginal dryness / atrophy - Local estrogen therapy is very effective Not Indicated / Contraindicated in: • Cardiovascular disease • HRT is not recommended for the prevention or treatment of cardiovascular disease. • In fact, studies (e.g., WHI trial) showed increased risk of stroke and thromboembolism, especially in older postmenopausal women or those starting HRT late. Why the Other Options Are Correct Uses: • A) Hot flash - HRT is the most effective treatment • C) Osteoporosis - Approved for prevention, especially in younger postmenopausal women • D) Vaginal dryness - Local estrogen therapy is first-line

questions.text: A 35-years yound female multigravida presenting with post coital bleeding, O/E vagina-normal,cervix-hypertrophied bilateral adnexa normal. What is the Next line of management:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 4 quadrant biopsy DONE THROUGH COLPOSCOPE. POSTCOITAL BLEEDING ? next step : Per Speculum examination + PAPS POSTCOITAL BLEEDING + VISIBLE GROWTH/ VISIBLY ABNORMAL CERVIX : BIOPSY MOST COMMON CAUSE OF DEATH IN CA CERVIX : UREMIA MOST SPECIFIC PRESENTATION OF CA CERVIX : postcoital bleeding while most common is irregular bleeding. Has Bimodal peak [most commonly in 3rd-4th decade, can also occur in 5th-6th decade. Hydroureter is stage 3 - treatment : Chemoradiation. Ovary is not removed in surgery for CA Cervix. Most important prognostic marker : Stage followed by LN status.

questions.text: Themes & Focus: Infertility and Tubal disease: Answer option list Lead in question: For the case below, choose the single most appropriate diagnosis from the above option list Case- A 35 year-old nulliparous woman with oligomenorrhea and infertility. Image of diagnostic laparoscopy is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) PCOS Enlarged ovaries seen with oligomenorrhea - a case of PCOS In endometriosis : Menorrhagia, intermenstrual bleeding will be present, not oligomenorrhea.

questions.text: Themes & Focus: Infertility and Tubal disease: Lead in question: For each case below, choose the single most appropriate diagnosis from the above option list Case- A 32 years-old woman with a BMI of 34 complains with irregular vaginal bleeding. On examination her endometrial thickness was 13mm with unequal thickened part at one area. The hysteroscopic image given below for diagnosis.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (F) Submucosal fibroid Solid, irregular, pale with surface vessels seen. Type 0 submucosal fibroid - completely intracavitary, can cause irregular bleeding. Polyp looks pink, fleshy and smooth.

questions.text: A 55 years old lady presented with menorrhagia and biopsy finding was simple endometrial hyperplasia with atypia. What is the definitive management for this patient
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hysterectomy Also bilateral salpingo oophorectomy. Hyperplasia with atypia : if asked next step – D&C with hysteroscopy, rule out malignancy then hysterectomy is the treatment of choice. Hyperplasia without atypia : MIRENA preferred over oral progesterone.

questions.text: Sentinel lymphnode biopsy most useful for
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Vulva For CA vulva : STAGING is clinical + surgical. For vulval lesion procedure is Radical local excision. If large lesion >2 cm/ central lesion/multicentric lesions → modified Radical vulvectomy. LN status : Stage IA : limited to vulva, less than or equal to 2 cms in size, no palpable LN : no lymphadenectomy is done. Stage IB to Stage II : size less than 2cm, Spread to lower 1/3rd of surrounding structures (urethra, vagina, anus), no palpable LNs → Unilateral lymphadenectomy : ipsilateral side [Inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy] If tumour is more than 2cm/central location/local extension → bilateral lymphadenectomy If LNs are palpable : debulking surgery of lymph nodes is done.

questions.text: Next line of management for a women who had been reported as CIN 3 seen on Pap smear
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Colposcopy and Leep CIN is a report on colposcopy now. Treatment of choice for CIN2 & CIN3 is LEEP, even if the family is complete.

questions.text: Which of the following doesn't imply choriocarcinoma after hydatiform mole treatment?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Plateau levels HCG Plateau levels HCG → It is more likely to be seen with invasive mole. In choriocarcinoma there is a rise of HCG. 2 criteria for GTN : 1. Day 1, Day 7, Day 14, Day 21 : 3 weeks if they show a plateau 2. Day 1, Day 7, Day 14 : if we see a rise over 2 weeks.

questions.text: Which of the following is the cause of male infertility with kartagener syndrome
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Asthenospermia Ciliary movement is affected, reduced motility. In cystic fibrosis → obstructive azoospermia with normal hormone levels. In Klinefelter → non obstructive azoospermia, high LH & FSH, LOW TESTOSTERONE.

questions.text: Which hormone is responsible for growth of follicles in early follicular phase?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) FSH This is the main function of FSH, also selection of dominant follicle. It also Plays a role in ovulation, during ovulation, both LH & FSH increase. [Single best answer is LH >FSH]

questions.text: Investigation of choice for vesicovaginal fistula
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Investigation of Choice): B) Three swab test • The 3-swab test (also called tampon test) is traditionally considered the investigation of choice (IOC) for vesicovaginal fistula (VVF) because: • It’s a simple, non-invasive bedside test • Helps differentiate types of fistulas (e.g., VVF vs. ureterovaginal) • Uses methylene blue dye in the bladder and checks which swab is stained/leaking Best/Confirmatory Test: A) Cystoscopy • Cystoscopy is the best and most definitive investigation, especially: • For visualizing the fistula directly • To assess location, size, and number • To check for ureteric involvement

questions.text: Which hormone has permissive role in puberty:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Leptin Neurotransmitter which suppresses GnRH before puberty : GABA [inhibitory] Neurotransmitter which stimulates GnRH at puberty : kisspeptin.

questions.text: Which of the following is primarily secreted fetal adrenal cortex
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) DHEAS Main product of the fetal adrenal gland. Function → DHEAS travels to placenta: acted upon by 2 enzymes : sulfatase & aromatase? placenta makes Estriol [E3] using DHEAS. PLACENTA uses Maternal LDL cholesterol to make progesterone. In the first 2 months estrogen & progesterone are synthesized from corpus luteum. Beyond 8 weeks they are : synthesized from placenta.

questions.text: A female is on Mala N for contraception. After the end of the first strip, there was no withdrawal bleeding. What should be done?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Urgent visit to hospital and check for pregnancy First thing is to rule out pregnancy.

questions.text: A 25-years-old lady with submucosal fibroid was undergoing myomectomy. The surgeon was using 1.5% glycine as irrigating fluid for the cavity. During the surgery the nurse informs the surgeon that there is a 500ml fluid deficit. What is the next step to be done?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Continue the surgery with careful monitoring of fluid status Glycine is an electrolyte deficient medium [others : sorbitol, mannitol]. Fluid deficit of 500 ml is for the doctor, for the patient it is fluid overload. Upper limit for electrolyte deficient media for fluid overload is 1 liter → cause hyponatremia at a lower level. Mannitol has the least risk of hyponatremia. Electrolyte deficient media are used with unipolar cautery. For Electrolyte rich media [ NS/RL] - upper limit is 2.5L, used with bipolar cautery/mechanical morcellators Once we reach the upper limits - stop the procedure. Gaseous distension media used is carbon dioxide, only used for diagnostic laparoscopy. Most common complication of hysteroscopy is perforation. Contraindications of hysteroscopy: 1. Pregnancy 2. Active genital herpes 3. Active Pelvic infection 4. Advanced cervical & endometrial Cancers Intrauterine pressure maintained while doing hysteroscopy : <100 mmHg.

choices.text: Give a generalized suture in bleeding area
Lift endopelvic fascia by putting ?ngers in vagina

questions.text: While performing Burch operation there was signi?cant bleeding and pooling of blood in the space of Retzius. The source of bleeding cannot be visualized. What is the next step in the management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Lift endopelvic fascia by putting fingers in vagina So that vessels are compressed and bleeding is stopped. Burch operation is gold standard surgery for stress urinary incontinence [abdominal surgery] In Burch colposuspension → suspension of proximal urethra to cooper's ligament. Treatment of choice for SUI - TRANSOBTURATOR tape or transvaginal tape [TOT, TVT] - MIDURETHRAL SLING SURGERIES - day care vaginal surgeries. TVT - retropubic surgery, TOT is not a retropubic surgery, has fewer complications than TVT. Space of Retzius is a retropubic space → blind entry, vessels can be injured → causing bleeding.

questions.text: Which of the following is the important marker of male infertility in semen analysis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Motility Single best answer is Morphology followed by motility.

questions.text: When would you do endometrial biopsy in post-menopausal bleeding if endometrial thickness is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 5mm ENDOMETRIAL THICKNESS MORE THAN 4MM → investigation of choice for postmenopausal bleeding : ENDOMETRIAL BIOPSY is done. If ET is less than or equal to 4mm - wait & watch, has persistent postmenopausal bleeding? endometrial biopsy is done.

choices.text: Radical vulvectomy with unilateral LN dissection
Radical vulvectomy with bilateral LN dissection

questions.text: A 76-years-old female presented with non-healing ulcer on labia majora for 6 months measuring 2x3 cm with no palpable lymphadenopathy. Biopsy shows squamous cell carcinoma. Management includes?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Radical vulvectomy with bilateral LN dissection If lesion is bigger than 2cm/ central location/ extending to lower → of any of the surrounding structures [urethra/vagina/anus], multicentric → radical vulvectomy with bilateral inguino-femoral lymphadenectomy. Stage 1A : less than or equal to 2cm & stromal invasion is less than 1cm Stage 1B : more than 2 cm or stromal invasion more than 1mm. Stage 1A : less than 2cm with no palpable LN : no lymphadenectomy done. Stage 1B : can be less than 2cm , more than 1mm stromal invasion : unilateral lymphadenectomy is done.

questions.text: Absolute contraindication for CuT insertion?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Copper IUD (Cu-T) is a highly effective, long-acting reversible contraceptive method. However, it has specific contraindications, and menorrhagia (heavy menstrual bleeding) is considered an absolute contraindication. ? Why B) Menorrhagia is Correct: • Copper IUD can increase menstrual bleeding and cramps, especially in the first few months. • In women with pre-existing menorrhagia, it can worsen symptoms and lead to anemia. • Therefore, Cu-T is contraindicated in such cases, and alternatives like LNG-IUS (Mirena) may be preferred, which can actually reduce bleeding. Evaluation of Other Options: • A) Unmotivated person - Not an absolute contraindication; may lead to noncompliance, but not a medical barrier. • C) Previous ectopic pregnancy - Relative contraindication, not absolute. Cu-T actually reduces the overall risk of pregnancy, including ectopic. However, if pregnancy does occur, ectopic risk is higher. • D) Previous history of abortion - Not a contraindic

questions.text: A 14-years-old girl presented with absent thelarche. On examination uterus was present. Investigations showed high FSH. Karyotype is XY. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Gonadal dysgenesis High FSH is suggestive of Gonadal dysgenesis. In AIS : FSH is normal, LH is very high [no negative feedback from testosterone as the testosterone receptor is insensitive]. In kallmann syndrome, both LH FSH levels are VERY LOW. ADRENAL HYPERPLASIA : normal FSH levels, 46XX, most common cause of female Pseudohermaphrodite: CAH. SWYERS : 46XY gonadal dysgenesis.

questions.text: SRY region is located in?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Short arm of Y chromosome The SRY gene provides instructions for making a protein called the sex-determining region Y protein. This protein is involved in male-typical sex development, which usually follows a certain pattern based on an individual's chromosomes. It is present on the short arm of Y chromosome.

questions.text: In a 46XY female on doing amniocentesis complete gonadal dysgenesis was noted. Complete gonadal dysgenesis is caused by what in the SRY gene?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Complete gonadal dysgenesis (also known as Swyer syndrome) is typically caused by mutations in the SRY gene - which is responsible for initiating male sex determination on the Y chromosome. Key Points: • SRY gene = Sex-determining Region Y gene • Located on the short arm of the Y chromosome (Yp11.3) • Encodes a transcription factor that triggers testis development In Complete Gonadal Dysgenesis (46, XY): • A point mutation in the SRY gene disrupts its function • Result: No testis formation → no testosterone or AMH → phenotypic female with streak gonads and no secondary sexual characteristics Other Options: B) Deletion: Can also cause gonadal dysgenesis, but point mutations are more classically described in Swyer syndrome C) Translocation: Often associated with XX males (SRY translocated to X) D) Inversion: Rarely implicated

questions.text: In which of the following statements will you suspect primary amenorrhea? A. Failure to attain menarche by 15 years of age B. Failure to attain menarche even after 3 years of thelarche C. High levels of TSH and short stature D. Failure of development of breasts by 13 years of age
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) ABD Primary amenorrhea is said to be failure to achieve menarche by 15 years of age in the presence of secondary sexual characteristics or no menarche by 13 years of age in the absence of secondary sexual characteristics, or absence of menarche within 3 years of thelarche.

questions.text: A 15-year-old female presents with primary amenorrhea and signs of virilization. She has prepubertal development of breasts and pubic hair and is tanner stage 2. She has a blind-ended vagina and clitoromegaly. She has normal male testosterone levels. Her genotype is 46XY. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Diagnosis is Steroid 5-Alpha Reductase Deficiency • Enzyme converts testosterone → dihydrotestosterone (DHT) • DHT is critical for external male genitalia development • At birth: appears phenotypically female or ambiguous • At puberty: testosterone rises, leading to virilization (clitoromegaly, deep voice), but breast development is absent • Testosterone is normal or elevated, but DHT is low • Genitalia: blind vaginal pouch, no uterus (due to AMH from testes) Why not the other options? A) Complete AIS • Feminine appearance with well-developed breasts • No virilization (testosterone can’t act due to receptor defect) • Pubic/axillary hair sparse or absent C) Swyer syndrome (46,XY CGD) • Streak gonads → no AMH or testosterone • Female internal genitalia present • No virilization D) 17-alpha hydroxylase deficiency • Impaired sex steroid and cortisol synthesis • Leads to female phenotype in 46,XY • No virilization; presents with hypertension and hypokalemia

questions.text: Which of the following is not essential in the workup of a Turner Mosaic?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Anti-nuclear Antibodies Antiendomysial, and not anti nuclear antibodies should be tested as there is increased risk of Celiac disease. Karyotype should be done as Turner Mosaic- 45XO/46XY- increased chance of malignancy (gonadobastoma) because of Y chromosome. Congenital heart disease BAV>CoA, hence Echocardiography should be done. Increased risk of Autoimmune diseases like DM and Hashimoto’s thyroiditis, hence glucose tolerance test should be done. SNHL is common, hence audiometry must be done.

questions.text: A 38-year-old multigravida presents with 2 years of infertility and dyspareunia and dysmenorrhea. She has a retroverted uterus and tenderness in the pouch of douglas. Wht would be the next step of management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Clinical Scenario • 38-year-old woman • 2 years of infertility • Symptoms: Dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia • Exam findings: Retroverted uterus and tenderness in the pouch of Douglas (POD) • Suggestive of endometriosis Question: What is the next step in management? Correct Answer: D) TVS (Transvaginal Sonography) Explanation: • In a patient with infertility and symptoms suggestive of endometriosis, the next step in the workup should be a non-invasive imaging modality. • TVS is: • Easily available • Non-invasive • Helpful in identifying endometriomas, uterine abnormalities, and signs of deep infiltrating endometriosis • It also guides further management and whether invasive diagnostic procedures are necessary. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect as Next Step: • B) Diagnostic Laparoscopy • It is the investigation of choice (IOC) for diagnosing peritoneal endometriosis, but not the immediate next step. • Used after initial imaging suggests or con

choices.text: Pain begins 3 days prior to the onset of periods and is present up to the second day of the period.
Pain begins after few hrs after onset of periods and can last upto 48 hrs.
It is dependent on psychological factors
GnRH antagonists are the first line of treatment

questions.text: Which of the following statements about primary dysmenorrhea is true?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Primary dysmenorrhea is menstrual pain without any identifiable pelvic pathology, commonly seen in adolescents and young women. Key Features of Primary Dysmenorrhea: • Pain starts a few hours after the onset of menstruation, not days before • Usually peaks on day 1-2 and subsides within 48-72 hours • Caused by excess prostaglandin F2α (PGF2α) → uterine contractions & ischemia • Associated with nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and lower back pain Why the other options are incorrect: A) Pain begins 3 days prior to onset of periods and is present up to second day • False → This is more typical of secondary dysmenorrhea (e.g., endometriosis) C) Is dependent on psychological factors • False → While stress may influence pain perception, the cause is prostaglandin-mediated uterine contractions, not primarily psychological D) GnRH antagonists are first-line of treatment • False → First-line treatment is NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) to block prostaglandin synthesis. • OCPs (oral contraceptives) are second-line • GnRH analogs/antagonists are reserved for refractory or secondary causes (e.g., endometriosis)

choices.text: Weight loss + Metformin + Induction of ovulation with clomiphene
Weight loss + Metformin + Induction of ovulation with urinary gonadotropins
Weight loss + Finasteride + Induction of ovulation

questions.text: A 23-year-old female with 6 years of infertility, has a BMI of 33 and facial hair. Investigations reveal she has PCOS and spill from bilateral tubes. She and her husband are trying to conceive, what would be the best plan of management for this lady?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Weight loss + Folic acid, Try for spontaneous induction, if failed move to induction of ovulation First line of management of overweight or obese PCOS patient is lifestyle management, as even a 5% weight loss can lead to ovulatory cycles. She should try for spontaneous induction and if it fails, we can try ovulation induction. The best drug for ovulation induction is Letrozole followed by Clomiphene and if this also fails, then gonadotropins. If a patient is on Anti androgens like finasteride, she should not conceive as it can lead to ambiguous genitalia in male patient. The only indication of Metform is insulin resistance.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of pubertal menorrhagia?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Anovulation The most common cause of pubertal menorrhagia is Anovulation followed by bleeding disorder. Management: If Hb<10gm% and vitals are stable- high dose estrogen and progesterone pill given because severe bleeding will cause the endometrium to be thin. Progesterone cannot act on endometrium which is not estrogen primed, so estrogen should be given followed by progesterone. Unstable vitals- IV estrogen followed by OCPs Hb>10- mild bleeding- reassure and supplement IFA and NSAIDs.

questions.text: A lady on OCPs presents with white discharge with no itching or foul smell. It stains her underwear yellow in colour and on examination of the discharge, normal lactobacilli were present and pH was acidic. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) This woman has physiological (normal) vaginal discharge, and here’s why: Key features from the case: • White discharge • No itching, irritation, or foul smell • Stains underwear yellow – common with oxidation of normal discharge • Presence of normal lactobacilli • Acidic pH – consistent with normal vaginal environment (pH <4.5) Why other options are incorrect: • A) Candidiasis – Usually presents with itching, curd-like discharge, and pH remains <4.5, but inflammation is prominent, which is absent here. • C) Bacterial vaginosis – Discharge is usually thin, grayish-white, fishy smelling, and pH >4.5. Also shows clue cells, not lactobacilli. • D) Chlamydia infection – Often asymptomatic or presents with mucopurulent discharge, may have cervicitis, but doesn’t show normal flora dominance and typically needs NAAT for diagnosis.

questions.text: A 32 year old female presents with grey-white vaginal discharge and on gram stain of the discharge, clue cells are seen. Clue cells are
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Epithelial cells covered by bacteria Clue cells are epithelial cells of the vagina that get their distinctive stippled appearance by being covered with bacteria. They are a medical sign of bacterial vaginosis, particularly that caused by Gardnerella vaginalis a group of Gram-variable bacteria. This bacterial infection is characterized by a foul, fishy smelling, thin gray vaginal discharge, and an increase in vaginal pH from around 4.5 to over 5.5. It is a part of Amsel’s Diagnostic Criteria for Bacterial Vaginosis- In clinical practice, bacterial vaginosis is diagnosed by the presence of 3 out of 4 Amsel criteria: 1. Thin, homogenous or milky vaginal discharge 2. Vaginal pH greater than 4.5 (i.e. greater than normal) 3. Positive whiff test (fishy amine odor when 10 percent potassium hydroxide solution is added) 4. At least 20 percent clue cells (vaginal epithelial cells with borders obscured by adherent coccobacilli on wet-mount preparation or Gram stain).

questions.text: Choose the incorrectly matched option-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) A) Rectocele – Posterior colporrhaphy Correct • Posterior colporrhaphy is the standard surgical repair for rectocele (posterior vaginal wall prolapse). B) Uterine prolapse – Vaginal hysterectomy Correct • Vaginal hysterectomy is a common and appropriate definitive treatment for uterine prolapse, often combined with vault suspension. C) Vault prolapse – Sacrospinous ligament suspension Correct • Sacrospinous ligament fixation is a recognized procedure to treat vault prolapse after hysterectomy. D) Cystocele – Colposuspension Incorrect • Colposuspension (e.g., Burch procedure) is primarily used for stress urinary incontinence, not for cystocele. • The correct treatment for cystocele (anterior vaginal wall prolapse) is: • Anterior colporrhaphy

questions.text: Fructose is absent in the seminal fluid, which of the following statements is true regarding this:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Fructose in seminal fluid is mainly secreted by the seminal vesicles, and it serves as an energy source for sperm. If fructose is absent in seminal fluid, it typically indicates: A) Congenital absence of seminal vesicles • Seminal vesicles are the primary source of fructose • If congenitally absent, no fructose will be secreted into the ejaculate B) Obstruction of the ejaculatory duct • Even if seminal vesicles are present, blockage of the duct will prevent fructose-rich fluid from reaching the urethra • So fructose will be absent in the semen Therefore, both conditions can lead to absence of fructose in seminal fluid.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not given in endometriosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Endometriosis is an estrogen-dependent condition, and treatment focuses on suppressing estrogen to reduce growth and activity of ectopic endometrial tissue. Option-wise breakdown: • A) Estradiol – Not given • Stimulates endometrial growth • Giving estradiol worsens symptoms and lesion progression • Contraindicated in endometriosis management • B) Medroxyprogesterone acetate – Used • A progestin that causes decidualization and atrophy of endometrial tissue • Commonly used in both oral and injectable forms • C) Cabergoline – Can be used off-label • A dopamine agonist • May help in reducing angiogenesis and lesion size in refractory endometriosis • Occasionally used in experimental or adjunctive settings • D) Letrozole – Used • An aromatase inhibitor • Reduces estrogen production → suppresses endometrial implant activity • Used especially in refractory or deep endometriosis

questions.text: An 18 year old female presents with primary amenorrhea with breast tanner 4 and normal secondary sexual characteristics,. FSH levels-5.3 IU nd LH 12 IU. Karyotype-46XX. What's the diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Mullerian agenesis The correct answer is Mullerian agenesis. A girl is present with primary amenorrhea and given breast tanner and normal secondary character suggestive of normal estrogen level and functioning ovaries. The level of FSH and LH are within normal range suggesting the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis is functioning and karyotype 46XX is normal female karyotype suggest the Mullerian agenesis. Müllerian agenesis (also known as Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome) involves congenital absence of the uterus, fallopian tubes, and the upper part of the vagina. These patients have normal ovarian function and secondary sexual characteristics, as described. This aligns with the given data.

questions.text: Which micronutrient deficiency causes hypogonadism and delayed sexual maturity
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Key Effects of Zinc Deficiency: • Delayed sexual maturation/puberty • Hypogonadism (especially in males) • Growth retardation • Impaired wound healing • Immune dysfunction • Alopecia and dermatitis (especially around mouth and genital area) Zinc is essential for: • Gonadal development and hormone synthesis • Testosterone production • Proper functioning of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal (HPG) axis Seen in: • Acrodermatitis enteropathica (a rare inherited disorder of zinc absorption) • Malnourished children • Chronic diarrheal states or alcoholism

questions.text: A 14 year old female with acute retention of urine. She complains Of cyclical pain in abdomen. On examination, a tense blue swelling is seen on local examination. On PR examination- suprapubic bulge present. Her condition is most likely due to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Imperforate hymen A 14-year-old female with acute retention of urine, cyclical abdominal pain, and a tense blue swelling on local examination, along with a suprapubic bulge on rectal examination, is most likely suffering from Imperforate hymen An imperforate hymen can cause obstructed menstrual flow, leading to hematocolpos (accumulation of menstrual blood in the vagina), which presents as a tense, bluish bulge at the vaginal introitus. This can also cause acute urinary retention due to the mass effect of the accumulated blood.

questions.text: Recombinant HPV vaccine has which antigen
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The recombinant HPV vaccine contains the L1 protein, which is the major capsid protein of the human papillomavirus. Key Points: • L1 protein self-assembles into virus-like particles (VLPs) • These mimic the outer structure of HPV but lack viral DNA, making the vaccine non-infectious • Highly immunogenic, inducing strong neutralizing antibody response

questions.text: Virilizing ovarian tumour is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Arrhenoblastoma – • Type: Rare ovarian sex cord-stromal tumor • Hormonal activity: Androgen-secreting → causes virilization • Age group: Most common in young women (teens to 30s) Clinical Features: • Hirsutism • Deepening of voice • Amenorrhea or oligomenorrhea • Clitoromegaly • Breast atrophy • Increased serum testosterone Diagnosis: • Pelvic ultrasound or MRI: Solid ovarian mass • Labs: Elevated testosterone, normal DHEAS • Histopathology: Sertoli and Leydig cells arranged in tubules Treatment: • Surgical removal (usually unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy) • Most are benign or low-grade malignant with good prognosis

questions.text: A woman was taking DMPA regularly as contraception. But now she has come 14days late with respect to due date. What is advise
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Updated WHO guideline regarding missed or late DMPA injections: WHO Guidelines on Late DMPA Injections: • The grace period for DMPA (Depo-Provera) is now considered up to 4 weeks (28 days) after the scheduled injection date • So, if a woman comes within 4 weeks after her due date and: • She has no signs of pregnancy • She has not had unprotected intercourse since the due date → Then you can give the injection without requiring back-up contraception CDC (U.S.) Guidelines: Recommend a 2-week grace period (up to 15 weeks from the last injection) without needing backup contraception.

questions.text: Which of the following has risk of progression to borderline ovarian tumour
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) A) OCP intake • Protective against both benign and malignant epithelial ovarian tumors, including borderline tumors. • Not a risk factor — it reduces ovulatory cycles, which lowers risk. B) Functional ovarian cyst • These are benign and usually resolve spontaneously. • Do not progress to borderline or malignant tumors. C) PCOS (Polycystic Ovary Syndrome) • Associated with hormonal imbalance but not directly linked to borderline ovarian tumors. • Slightly increased risk for endometrial cancer, but not for BOTs. D) Nulliparity • Increased risk of epithelial ovarian tumors, including borderline tumors, likely due to more lifetime ovulations. • Repeated ovulation may cause surface epithelial trauma, promoting neoplastic changes.

questions.text: Image of reinkes crystal with history which tumour
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Reinke crystals are rod-shaped, eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions found exclusively in: Leydig cell tumors (also called interstitial cell tumors) • Seen in: Leydig cell tumors of the testis (and rarely, ovary) • Histology: Large polygonal cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, Reinke crystals (pathognomonic) • Hormonal activity: Often androgen-secreting, leading to precocious puberty in boys or virilization in women Other Options: • B) Sertoli cell tumor: No Reinke crystals; arranged in tubules • C) Yolk sac tumor (Endodermal sinus tumor): Characterized by Schiller-Duval bodies, AFP elevation, not Reinke crystals

questions.text: A obese girl comes with history of irregular cycles and hirsutism score 6. testosterone level 0.36ng/dl/her mother is diabetic and on medication. what should not be advised
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) This girl presents with: • Irregular cycles • Mild hirsutism (score of 6) • Normal testosterone level (0.36 ng/mL) • Positive family history of diabetes This points toward early or mild PCOS phenotype with potential metabolic risk, but clinical features are not severe. Why Option B is not advised at this stage: • Antiandrogens (e.g., spironolactone, cyproterone acetate) are typically added only if hirsutism is moderate to severe, and not controlled after 6 months of OCP use. • In a girl with mild hirsutism and normal testosterone, OCP alone is first-line. • Combining OCP and antiandrogens upfront is not standard practice in mild cases due to potential side effects and over-treatment. Other Options: A) OCP • Advised • First-line treatment to regulate cycles and reduce androgen symptoms. C) Lifestyle modification • Strongly recommended, especially with family history of diabetes. • Helps with insulin

questions.text: An IBQ on cervical smear and stain used (slide with blue background and very small blue cells)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Uses of Toluidine Blue in Cytology: 1. Rapid Staining Method (Modified Pap) • Used for quick screening of cervical smears • Cells stain blue to dark blue, nuclei are clearly visible • Helpful for immediate evaluation, such as in screen-and-treat programs • Allows for early identification of suspicious or abnormal cells 2. Vital Staining in Colposcopy • Applied to cervix to highlight suspicious areas • Dysplastic/neoplastic epithelium absorbs the dye more intensely Cell Appearance with Toluidine Blue: • Cells appear small and blue • Nuclear details are well preserved • High nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio stands out clearly in abnormal cells

questions.text: 65 year old lady with ovarian cancer. CT scan Shows omental caking and ascites and peritoneal metastasis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A 65-year-old woman with advanced-stage ovarian cancer (evidenced by omental caking, ascites, and peritoneal metastasis), the choice between primary debulking surgery and neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NACT) depends on: • Disease burden (extensive spread) • Patient’s age and performance status • Feasibility of achieving optimal cytoreduction upfront Why Option A (NACT First) is Preferred Here: • Extensive disease (omental caking + peritoneal metastases) makes optimal debulking difficult upfront. • Neoadjuvant chemotherapy: • Shrinks tumor burden • Improves likelihood of complete cytoreduction during surgery • Reduces perioperative morbidity in older or high-risk patients Current Guidelines (e.g., NCCN, ESMO): • Neoadjuvant chemotherapy + interval debulking is recommended in patients with: • High tumor load • Poor surgical candidates • Or when optimal debulking (no gross residual disease) is unlikely

questions.text: 26 year old P1L1 presents with abdominal pain. She has a past history of rheumatic heart disease for which she has undergone mitral valve replacement surgery and is on oral tablet Warfarin 3mg OD. On examination 14 weeks abdominal mass was felt. On USG, 8*6 cm unilocular cyst with reticular pattern was observed in left ovary. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) • The cyst is unilocular, 8×6 cm, and shows a reticular pattern—all features suggestive of a benign ovarian lesion, such as a hemorrhagic cyst. • In pregnancy, most simple ovarian cysts <10 cm resolve spontaneously, especially if they appear benign on ultrasound. • Warfarin use increases the risk of bleeding, so surgical intervention should be avoided unless clearly indicated. • Therefore, the safest and most evidence-based next step is to monitor with a follow-up ultrasound in 6–12 weeks to check for resolution or any change in morphology. Incorrect Options: A. Measure CA-125 • CA-125 is not reliable in pregnancy because it can be falsely elevated due to normal physiological changes. • This can mislead the diagnosis and potentially prompt unnecessary investigations or interventions. • Not recommended for evaluating ovarian cysts during pregnancy unless there are clear signs of malignancy. C. Surgical intervention • Surgery is not the first line for a benign-looking cyst in a stable, asymptomatic pregnant patient. • The patient is on Warfarin, which significantly increases surgical bleeding risk. • Surgery is only considered if there is suspicion of malignancy, torsion, rupture, or persistent growth after follow-up. D. MRI pelvis • MRI is used when ultrasound findings are inconclusive or if there’s suspicion of malignancy that cannot be clarified with USG. • In this case, the ultrasound clearly shows a simple unilocular cyst, and there's no indication for MRI at this stage. • MRI is not the next best step when ultrasound provides sufficient information.

questions.text: Dr. Priya is conducting a talk on the screening of cervical cancer with Pap smear. She works in a clinic in a low resource setting and she was planning to screen a woman in her 20s. Which of the following is true regarding cervical cancer screening guidelines in her workplace?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In low-resource settings, the Pap smear (cytology-based screening) is the standard and most feasible method for cervical cancer screening. According to WHO guidelines and other global cervical cancer screening guidelines, Pap smear screening should start at age 21, regardless of sexual activity. After that, it should be repeated every 3 years if the results are normal. This approach is cost-effective and can be easily implemented even in settings where HPV testing is not widely available. For women in their 20s, this is the most appropriate and widely accepted guideline. Why Option A is Incorrect (Co-testing every 5 years starting at 25 years): Co-testing (Pap smear + HPV testing) is indeed a good option for cervical cancer screening, but it is usually recommended starting at age 30 in high-resource settings where both tests are available. This is not typically implemented in low-resource settings, where HPV testing may be too costly or unavailable. Additionally, the 25-year age recommendation is not aligned with guidelines for low-resource areas, where Pap smear alone is typically used. Why Option C is Incorrect (HPV testing every 5 years starting at 30 years): HPV testing is a valid option in high-resource settings, but it is not recommended for women under 30 years old due to the high rate of transient infections in younger women. Furthermore, HPV testing is often not feasible in low-resource settings due to lack of infrastructure and cost. Therefore, starting at age 30 in such settings is not practical. In this case, Pap smear is the more accessible and recommended choice for women in their 20s. Why Option D is Incorrect (Pap smear every 5 years starting at 21 years): Although Pap smears are indeed recommended for cervical cancer screening, the interval for normal Pap smears is every 3 years, not 5 years. Extending the interval to 5 years may delay the detection of pre-cancerous changes, which is why this interval is not recommended for routine screening, especially in younger women.
